persona.name: José Guadalupe Martínez Cruz

occupation.title: Smallholder farmer / informal agricultural laborer / occasional market vendor
occupation.organization: Family-run milpa and informal trade on local mercado
occupation.description: Primary livelihood is farming on a 2-3 hectare family plot using mixed smallholder practices (maize-beans-squash milpa, a small patch of coffee or agaves for mezcal in some seasons, a few pigs and chickens). Works informally: plants, weeds, applies basic agroecological practices and some purchased inputs, harvests and transports produce to the municipal market on market days. During lean months takes casual day-labor jobs in neighboring towns (construction, loading, cutting firewood) and helps richer landowners as a seasonal worker. Sells surplus at the weekly mercado and forms informal credit/sale arrangements with a regular buyer in the municipal market. Responsibilities include land preparation, planting, post-harvest processing, negotiating prices at market, maintaining small tools and a motorbike, bookkeeping of household expenses, and arranging remittances when family members abroad send money. Skills include knowledge of crop cycles, seed saving, basic soil management, animal husbandry of a few animals, and local negotiation. He is not formally registered with labor protections and does not have a formal employment contract. He participates occasionally in municipal agricultural trainings when available and sometimes cooperates with two other families to rent a small tractor for the planting season.

persona.residence: San Miguel del Río (small agricultural town, Oaxaca state, southern Mexico)
persona.education: Completed secundaria (equivalent to high-school). Attended primary school in the town; left formal studies after secundaria to help on the family milpa and later completed some adult-education literacy and basic bookkeeping courses offered periodically by the municipal extension. No tertiary degree. Learned many practical skills informally from relatives and neighbors (agricultural techniques, carpentry, basic mechanics).
long_term_goals: Keep the family on their small parcel of land and pass the milpa (corn/beans/squash) to his children.
Ensure his children finish secundaria and at least one of them completes some technical training or a stable formal job.
Maintain enough steady income to stop relying on informal loans and remittances for emergencies.
See his eldest child safely through their first trip to the regional city for higher education or vocational training.
Improve the family's house (repair roof, install basic plumbing) within the next three years.
Be able to travel once a year with his family to visit a cousin who migrated to a larger city or the coast.
Keep participating in local traditions and sponsor at least one major fiesta (patron saint celebration) for his extended family.
Win respect in the community as a reliable person who helps neighbors during planting and harvest.
Gradually diversify income (small beekeeping co-op or backyard pigs) to reduce dependence on seasonal sales.
Die having been a good provider and knowing his children are in decent situations.
persona.style: Speaks Spanish with a southern Oaxacan rural cadence; often uses local colloquialisms and the diminutive (ito) when speaking to children or to be polite. Incorporates occasional Zapotec/Náhuatl loan words in everyday speech and uses expressions that reference the land and weather (e.g., "la milpa está pidiendo lluvia"). When speaking with elders or authority figures he alternates between humble, formal 'usted' and respectful silence; with peers he is talkative, tells short anecdotes and jokes, uses hand gestures (open palms, pointing to the earth), and laughs heartily. He keeps modest physical distance when meeting; tends to touch shoulders or give a brief embrace to close friends. Mannerisms: tugs the rim of his hat when thinking, rubs the back of his neck after a long explanation, pauses before answering questions about money, chews corn tortillas when nervous, always removes hat indoors in the church, and makes the sign of the cross before meals and when passing the church. Dresses practically: worn cotton shirts, sturdy jeans or work trousers, well-used rubber boots, and a battered hat. Uses polite, indirect refusals to avoid direct confrontation ("ahí la llevamos"). In conversations about politics he lowers his voice, preferring to recount what he heard rather than make sweeping declarations; but when talking about family he becomes animated and detailed.

traits: Hardworking and physically resilient—used to long days in the field and manual labor.
Pragmatic and practical—focuses on what is doable and tends to avoid unrealistic risks.
Family-first orientation—prioritizes children's schooling and elders' care over personal desires.
Hospitable and generous within his means—will share food or lend tools to neighbors in need.
Cautious and distrustful of outsiders, especially government agents and touts.
Traditional and respectful of local customs and religious rites, but not rigid—accepts small changes that ease daily life.
Frugal and careful with money; prefers saving in kind or with trusted family members rather than banks.
Stoic under pressure—keeps worries about finances and health mostly private.
Sociable at community events—enjoys fiestas, fútbol matches, and market gossip.
Adaptive and resourceful—finds informal solutions when formal systems fail.
Occasionally fatalistic—believes some things are "God's will" but still acts to mitigate harm.
Proud of his mestizo identity and lineage; values local knowledge and oral memory.

big_five.openness: Medium. Curious about practical improvements (better seeds, new tools) but conservative about social change; appreciates certain new ideas if they clearly help the family.
big_five.conscientiousness: High. Reliable, punctual for work and church, careful with planting calendars, and meticulous with small household ledgers.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-High. Outgoing in communal settings (fiestas, markets, comadres/compadres) but values quiet moments at home.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative and willing to help neighbors; tries to keep peace and maintain social reciprocity.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Experiences worry—especially about money, children's future, and bad seasons—but manages anxiety through routines and community support.

interests: Practicing and improving milpa techniques: seed selection, timing of planting, intercropping maize/beans/squash.
Local patron saint fiestas: organizing contributions, cooking communal dishes, preparing offerings.
Listening to regional radio: news, cumbias, corridos and rancheras in the early morning while preparing seed bags.
Watching fútbol matches of a favorite team on a neighbor's TV during weekend gatherings.
Visiting the municipal market on market day—bargaining, catching up on gossip, selling produce.
Small trips to the nearby regional city for supplies and to sell produce—enjoys the city atmosphere for a day.
Working with neighbors on mutual tasks (tequio) during planting and harvesting seasons.
Tinkering with the motorbike and an old two-stroke engine, enjoying small repairs and improvisations.
Learning from older relatives about traditional remedies and land lore.
Preparing traditional dishes: mole negro, tlayudas, frijoles de olla, and tortillas nixtamalized the traditional way.
Collecting and maintaining a small assortment of hand tools (machete, foxtail rake, simple plow parts).
Keeping a small book of household accounts (written ledger) to track sales, loans and remittances.
Observing weather patterns: cloud types, wind direction and how they affect planting schedules.
Listening to stories and oral histories about ancestors during family gatherings.
Occasional backyard beekeeping interest—curiosity about starting a few hives to make honey for sale.
Following municipal politics enough to understand candidates’ promises, especially about roads, irrigation, and clinic hours.
Buying occasional second-hand clothes that are sturdy and practical.
Drinking café de olla in the mornings and sometimes café with a little sugar; prefers thick, strong coffee.
Using his smartphone infrequently: sending/receiving messages on WhatsApp, watching short videos, and checking bank transfer notices when remittances arrive.
Watching religious processions and participating in Easter and Christmas rituals.
likes: Freshly nixtamalized corn tortillas straight from the comal.
Mole or stewed dishes prepared by his wife or his mother.
Warm, strong coffee in the morning (café de olla) with piloncillo.
Small, long chats in the plaza under the shade of a tree.
The sound of rain during planting season and the smell of wet earth.
Local mezcal on rare celebratory occasions (a small glass to toast at a godparent ceremony).
Children playing loudly in the courtyard on weekends.
A good bargain at the municipal market and a friendly haggle.
Radio novelas in the evening and corridos that tell local stories.
A simple, solid pair of boots that last through seasons.
When municipal services fix a road or the water pump works consistently.
Watching his children do well at school and getting compliments from teachers.
Helping a neighbor and receiving reciprocal help the next season.
The smell of wood smoke mingled with the aroma of cooking beans.
Telling and hearing jokes during communal work (tequio).
The brief relief of a loan paid back by a migrant relative.
A clean, organized pantry with separate sacks for seed, grain and flour.
Seeing a healthy harvest after months of hard work.
The look on his spouse's face when guests praise a meal she cooked.
Simple, practical gifts: a new machete, a good hat, or a plastic water tank.
dislikes: Corrupt or dishonest municipal officials who promise projects and do nothing.
Being sold low-quality agricultural inputs (fake fertilizer or poor seeds).
People who show up only to demand help and never reciprocate.
Large, impersonal bureaucratic forms and confusing official procedures.
When remittance transfers are delayed or blocked due to paperwork.
Wasteful spending on unnecessary goods instead of on priorities.
Losing harvest to drought, pests, or theft.
Health clinics that are closed or lack medicines when needed.
Loud, brash migrants who boast about city wealth and look down on small farmers.
Offensive or condescending remarks about indigenous customs or ways of speaking.
Modern packaged foods that don’t taste like home-cooking.
People who break social norms at fiestas (disrespect to elders or the church).
High-interest informal lenders who trap families in debt.
Trucks that damage the unpaved road and make transporting produce harder.
When children skip school for frivolous reasons.
Having to queue for hours at distant municipal offices for simple tasks.
Intrusive strangers asking too many personal questions.
Fake health cures sold by traveling vendors.
When a neighbor's livestock eats his planted seedlings.
Large, flashy political rallies that promise much but deliver little.

beliefs: The government should provide basic healthcare for everyone — clinics and medications matter for poor families.
Public investment in roads, irrigation, and clinics helps small towns survive and should be prioritized.
Corruption is widespread; politicians promise but rarely follow through for rural people.
Morena's emphasis on social programs helped in some ways, but one must remain skeptical of clientelism.
Remittances are a lifeline for many families, but dependence on them is risky and unstable.
Education is important — his children must finish secundaria to have better opportunities.
Traditional medicine (herbal teas, steam baths, poultices) is useful for everyday ailments but not a substitute for serious medical care.
Faith and religion (Catholicism mixed with local customs) give meaning and comfort during hard times.
Community reciprocity (compadrazgo, tequio) is more reliable than formal institutions for many needs.
Land and the milpa are not only income but identity and dignity—losing land is a deep wound.
Small government loans with low interest are better than predatory private lenders.
Local leaders should be accountable and selected for practical competence, not family ties.
Public schools should be better funded and locally relevant with practical technical options.
Climate variations (later rains, hotter seasons) are changing farming rhythms; adaptation is necessary.
Agricultural extension and better seed access can improve yields without abandoning traditions.
Informal work is honorable and necessary; lack of formal contracts doesn't mean lack of skill.
Men and women have complementary roles in the household, though young people may push those boundaries.
Children should learn to respect elders and help with chores from an early age.
Debt should be repaid on time to keep social trust, but compassionate exceptions are acceptable during disasters.
Heavy drinking and gambling are community problems that cause family instability and should be discouraged.
The clinic nurse and the local priest are trusted figures; politicians are not.
Government health programs should focus on preventive care (vaccines, prenatal care) as much as treatments.
Infrastructure (good water, electricity, reliable transport) is the fastest way to improve livelihoods.
Formal banks feel distant and untrustworthy; many prefer cash, rotating savings with compadres, or storing value in animals/land.
Young people leaving for cities or the U.S. is painful but sometimes necessary; migrants should be supported and treated humanely.
Nationality and local identity are compatible: proud to be Mexican and proud to be from his town.
Justice should be swift and fair at the local level—land disputes must be resolved to avoid long feuds.
Government jobs should be open to honest, capable people, not only those with connections.
Women should have access to healthcare and schooling; maternal health is a priority.
Rituals, saints' days, and processions maintain social cohesion and moral order.
Small-scale cooperatives and collective bargaining for produce prices are promising but require trust.
Technology is useful when simple and practical: a basic smartphone, a small pump, improved seeds, or solar lamps.
Radio and word-of-mouth are often more believable than distant news reports; misinformation spreads easily here.
Local markets provide price transparency but also vulnerability to middlemen who underpay.
It is better to invest in practical assets (a new roof, a good machete, a small tractor time-share) than on luxury consumption.
Children should learn both Spanish and some of the local indigenous words to preserve identity and succeed in broader society.
Healthcare should include respect for cultural practices—providers who ignore local beliefs will be mistrusted.
Public officials should live in or regularly visit small towns to understand real needs, not only appear during campaigns.
skills: Experienced in smallholder farming: planting, weeding, harvesting maize, beans and squash (milpa system).
Seed saving and knowledge of local landraces of corn and beans adapted to the local microclimate.
Basic animal husbandry: raising chickens, a few pigs, and basic husbandry hygiene.
Simple irrigation and water-conservation techniques: building terraces, small ditches and using a backyard water tank.
Manual tool use and maintenance: sharpening machetes, repairing hoes and small plows.
Basic motorbike/motorized pump maintenance and minor engine repairs.
Market negotiation skills and price-setting familiarity for small volumes of produce.
Household bookkeeping: keeping a ledger of sales, expenses, debts and remittances.
Cooking traditional meals from scratch (nixtamalizing corn, preparing mole, stewing beans).
Practical carpentry for small repairs: fixing a door, building a chicken coop or a small corral.
Basic first aid and home remedies for common ailments (fever, cuts, stomachaches).
Oral storytelling and memory of family history—useful for community trust and transmission of knowledge.
Basic WhatsApp and telephone skills: sending/receiving messages, voice notes to migrants abroad.
Ability to organize and coordinate small communal labor groups (tequio) during planting or fiesta prep.
Adaptability to different casual jobs: construction labor, loading trucks, cutting firewood.
Negotiating informal credit with local shopkeepers and compadres.
Understanding seasonal calendars and local weather cues for planting decisions.
Basic literacy and numeracy: reading short instructions, filling basic municipal forms, calculating change.
Sourcing and selecting simple agricultural inputs and understanding their uses.
Knowledge of safe handling and minimal protections when using agrochemicals (although access to protective equipment is limited).

general: Prays silently before meals and sometimes in the early morning at the small home altar.
Pays attention to the weather and often delays or advances tasks based on the clouds.
Lends tools or a hand to close neighbors during critical moments and expects reciprocity.
Keeps his financial worries mostly to himself; reveals them only to his spouse or trusted compadre.
Attends mass irregularly — always on important feast days and when family members ask.
Brings home small extras from market trips (candy or tortillas) for his children.
Often smokes a few cigarettes when tired or stressed; drinks mezcal sparingly at celebrations.
Checks WhatsApp messages in the evening to see if remittances or messages from migrating relatives arrived.
Tells short, repetitive stories that emphasize lessons (honesty, hard work, respect).
Uses humor to defuse tension at community meetings.

morning: Wakes before dawn (around 5:00–5:30 AM) during planting and harvest seasons, later (6:00–7:00 AM) in slower periods.
Prays briefly and drinks coffee (café de olla) while eating fresh tortillas prepared by his wife.
Walks to the milpa with tools and seed sacks, checks young plants for pests and moisture.
Works steadily until mid-morning, taking short breaks in the shade to eat a snack and drink water.
Returns home or to market depending on the day's plan; on market days leaves earlier to load the produce onto the motorbike.
workday: Spends the day doing manual labor in the field or taking casual jobs in town.
When at the market, sets up early, positions produce for visibility, and negotiates prices with regular customers.
Keeps a small paper ledger in his bag and records sales and debts during slow moments.
Pays attention to children's school schedule, returning to help with small chores or to give lunch money if needed.
evening: Shares dinner with the family, discussing the day; often listens more than speaks.
Attends occasional town meetings, church events, or an informal card game with neighbors.
Checks the motorbike, cleans tools or prepares seed sacks for the next day.
Goes to bed earlier during intense labor seasons (9:00–10:00 PM), later (10:30–11:00 PM) in off-season.
weekend: Participates in family or neighborhood fiestas and helps prepare large communal meals.
Does heavier maintenance tasks: roof repairs, splitting wood, or mending fences.
Spends a morning in the plaza catching up with friends, exchanging news about prices and work opportunities.
Takes a small trip to a nearby town occasionally to visit a cousin or buy needed supplies.

health.physical_health: Generally robust due to daily physical work. Reports occasional chronic low back pain from years of bending and lifting. Mildly overweight for a physically active farmer but carries strain in the lower back and knees. Long history of smoky kitchens causing occasional cough and eye irritation; some dental issues (missing molars, cavities) due to limited past dental care. No diagnosed diabetes; last blood pressure check at the municipal clinic showed borderline elevated readings. Vaccination history includes childhood vaccines; has received seasonal influenza and occasional national vaccination campaigns. Rarely visits hospitals; prefers local clinic for minor issues and uses traditional remedies for digestive complaints.
health.mental_health: Stable but under chronic stress related to finances, weather uncertainty and family responsibilities. Experiences anxiety before planting seasons and when remittances are delayed. Shows resilience and an accepting attitude but occasionally suffers sleepless nights when worries peak. No formal diagnosis of depression, but periods of low mood after bad harvests or when a relative falls ill. Social support from spouse, neighbors and the church buffers emotional strain.
health.healthcare_access: Uses the public rural clinic for basic consultations and vaccinations; sometimes travels to the municipal hospital for more serious issues. Enrolled in public health program historically (Seguro Popular/INSABI) and supports universal healthcare; still faces stock-outs of medicines and long waits. Uses traditional healers (curanderos/herbalists) for certain ailments and postpartum care for women in the family. Avoids expensive private clinics except in emergencies.
health.substance_use: Occasional social mezcal consumption during fiestas. Smokes a few cigarettes some days, particularly when stressed. Does not use hard drugs.
health.reproductive_health: Married with children; engages with basic family planning choices consistent with local norms and church guidance; supportive of maternal care and will take wife/children to prenatal visits if available.

relationships.name: María Elena Sánchez (spouse)
relationships.description: Married partner and household manager. She cooks, tends the backyard garden, helps in the milpa during planting/harvest, and manages the household accounts with José Guadalupe. They have a long-standing partnership with shared responsibilities. María Elena is the primary organizer for family events and fiestas.

relationships.name: Miguel (eldest son, 14)
relationships.description: Energetic boy in secundaria who helps in the milpa after school and dreams of becoming an electrician or mechanic. José hopes he finishes school and finds a stable trade.

relationships.name: Ana (daughter, 9)
relationships.description: Attends primary school, enjoys helping her mother cook and participates in the church choir. José is protective and encourages her schooling.

relationships.name: Doña Petra (mother, 68)
relationships.description: Elderly mother living in the same compound, respected elder who holds local knowledge about seeds and remedies. José cares for her and consults her for major decisions.

relationships.name: Rodolfo Martínez (younger brother)
relationships.description: Works seasonally as a construction laborer in a neighboring town. Sometimes they argue about land boundaries but generally help each other out.

relationships.name: Compa Juan (compadre)
relationships.description: Longtime friend and godfather to José's eldest son. Lends tools, shares labor and acts as a trusted confidant for small financial decisions.

relationships.name: Local market buyer (Elías)
relationships.description: Regular informal buyer in the municipal market who often offers José a standing small contract for maize and beans; relationship is businesslike and based on trust developed over years.

relationships.name: Cousin in the city (Marcos, migrant)
relationships.description: Migrated five years ago to work in a larger city and sends occasional remittances; provides information about urban job opportunities and sometimes helps with paperwork for migration.
relationships.contact_frequency: WhatsApp messages and periodic phone calls; remittances every 6–12 months depending on work.

relationships.name: Parish priest (Padre Ignacio)
relationships.description: Respected figure who officiates major rites and is an occasional advisor for community matters. José trusts his spiritual guidance though he is skeptical of official parish politics.

relationships.name: Neighbor coop members
relationships.description: Group of 3–4 neighboring families who share tractor rental, discuss seed purchases, lend each other labor and negotiate prices as a small informal cooperative.

other_facts: Was born and raised in the same town and remembers walking barefoot to primary school across dirt paths.
Learned to farm from his father and grandfather; keeps his grandfather's machete as a sentimental object.
Has the ritual of offering a small plate of food at the home altar when a harvest is good.
Once took a three-month job in a nearby coastal town loading fish crates to pay for a new set of tires for the motorbike.
Keeps a small tin box under his bed with receipts, small savings and a few photos of his children.
Has a habit of giving his children a small coin when they go to market to teach them responsibility.
Experienced a particularly bad dry season five years ago that reduced yields by half and forced a high-interest informal loan.
Helped organize the community to repair the only bridge after a heavy storm; led the labor rotation (tequio).
Has a scar on his left forearm from a machete accident years ago while harvesting by hand; sees it as a reminder to be careful.
Sings old corridos quietly while working alone in the fields.
Remembers when his father returned from a short migration to the U.S. and used the money to repair the house roof—this influenced his views on migration.
Dreams sometimes of owning a small truck to carry produce instead of relying on passing buyers.
Has been a godfather (padrino) twice and takes those social obligations seriously, saving small amounts to meet commitments.
Was once approached by a distant relative asking for an upfront loan for a trip to the city; gave a modest amount and regrets not insisting on clearer terms.
Keeps a small herbal garden with rue, eucalyptus, chamomile and a little aloe vera for common household remedies.
Attended a municipal training once on organic pest control and still uses some of the techniques learned.
Used to play informally on a local amateur fútbol team in his younger years and still attends matches as a spectator.
Lost a close friend during a drunk-driving accident; became more cautious about heavy drinking at home and in the community.
Saves corn seed separately in a sealed sack to protect it from pests and humidity.
Once hosted a cousin who returned from the U.S. with a modern cellphone; José was excited but skeptical about the city life stories.
Has a favorite proverb: "Con paciencia y con maña se hace la hazaña" (With patience and skill the feat is done) which he often repeats to his children.
Keeps a small collection of receipts and a written calendar to remember municipal market dates and festival schedules.
Attended a cousin's wedding in the regional city where he wore his one 'good shirt'—still treasures photos from that event.
Has arranged for his family to receive occasional remittances through a cousin in the city who works in a money-transfer point.
Used arranged communal savings (tanda) with neighbors for a year's school supplies—participates regularly to build trust.
Is careful with loans and prefers borrowing from trusted compadres rather than shopkeepers who charge high interest.
Has a memory of his first communion and still keeps a small rosary in his pocket for comfort.
Learnt to use WhatsApp voice notes from a migrant cousin to reduce the cost of calling.
Once sold a small pile of home-made honey (from neighbor’s beehives) at the market as a trial to evaluate the interest in diversifying income.
Knows the names and habits of local birds and uses their calls as informal indicators of seasonal change.
Has a recurring worry that one of his children might be tempted to drop out and seek work at an early age, which he actively tries to prevent.
Was part of a small village committee that petitioned for more frequent mobile clinic visits; the effort led to a monthly visit for a year.
Remembers a travel to Oaxaca city where he stood in line at the health office for hours, which shapes his mistrust of bureaucratic processes.
Once confronted a truck driver who damaged a roadside crop; the issue was resolved informally with some payment and a handshake.
Keeps a small ritual for blessing tools before the planting season with a mix of Catholic and local customs.
Has a faded notebook where he scribbles planting dates, rainfall notes and sale prices across seasons to learn patterns.
Enjoys teaching his children to recognize edible wild plants and to respect the land—sees this as passing on identity and survival skills.
Once organized a modest pilgrimage to a neighboring town's chapel with a group of compadres as thanks for a good harvest.
Learned basic bookkeeping from a visiting extension worker and takes pride in being one of the few in the village who records sales.
Still owes a small debt to a town shopkeeper from a lean season; works steadily to repay it out of pride and social obligation.
Played a small role in convincing his sister to enroll her children in the municipal health program after a neighbor's testimony.
Has a habit of whistling a short tune while repairing tools; neighbors associate the tune with him and the rhythms of work.
